description:
China Beach isn't as well known as the very crowded Ocean Beach, and it isn't anywhere near as popular as neighboring Baker Beach.  It's a beach in a small cove that allows swimming.  It's a somewhat steep walk down from the parking area (which is fairly limited) to the beach.  

On a clear day, the views of the Golden Gate Bridge from the beach can take your breath away; on foggy days it can look eerie enough to have been lifted from a Stephen King novel ;-)

While swimming is allowed, it should be noted that the water has strong undertows, and the water temperature is colder than an IRS Auditor's heart; caution is advised even for swimmers equipped with wet suits.

The beach and the cove were named for the Chinese laborers and fisherman who used to camp in the area during the 19th century.  There's a monument of sorts called China Beach Rock that was built in the 1980s to honor these early settlers.  Here's the inscription from China Beach Rock:

"Since gold rush times, this cove was used as a campsite by many of the Chinese fishermen who worked in and around San Francisco Bay. Their efforts to supply the needs of a young city helped establish one of the area's most important industries and traditions."
author: Janey E.

description:
CARRIED our dogs down to the beach just to take a picture. Halfway there, an old dude in his speedo harassed us about no dogs allowed. When I said we were simply holding the dogs and walking down to take pictures, he kept going on about the park ranger. (It's a Sunday.) 
I've been to this beach about half a dozen times and there are no park rangers on this beach and whoever is dressed as a park ranger is a fake and actually has no authority to issue any citation. If you have an legitimate emotional support dog, call the cops on this senile old man.
My guess is he's a local and wants to limit the amount of people who go here so him and his elderly lady friend and tan themselves crisp without much interruption. Spoiler alert, I also live in this city and you don't own this beach.
author: Natasha W.

description:
Me. My mind. It's here again. It's always here. A photo of Baker Beach brought me back there, and this time it was a dream. China Beach. She came to me in my dreams--as vivid as the bright orange sunset, as soft as the foam that crawls up the sand. That haunting view of the hills across the mouth of the bay; like a redhead with the last embers of light crawling up the shoulders of land on her headlands. That's what I saw in my dream.

It is still with me, it's been with me all day. It's been with me since last summer. Whether a day goes by, or a week, or a year -- when something is a part of you, it's just a part of you. I haven't been here in a while now, but in one night, one dream, I'm transported back and everything is right again. I can see the bridge. I can see the way across. 

Oh, it can see a little foreboding to get from city to beach. But I promise those stairs are safe, one step at a time, and when you get here you will be happier than you ever were in your old life, just a few blocks from where I am now. Just have faith, and let's go to the beach, look out at the waves, and dare to whisper dreams of all the things we're going to do now. It's not just a dream, it's real.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: Beautiful spot for picnics, sandcastles and walks. Swimming is very enjoyable with views of the bay. When clear you can see Monterey coastline! Go you will not be disappointed!
author: Andrea K.

description:
On our last adventure day on the west coast, my friend and I decided that these Floridians wanted to see a Cali beach. As we were looking up options, we happened to see China Beach suggested on google. I'm so glad we went here! This beach offers a perfect view of cascading cliff sides, the mountains and the Golden Gate Bridge all in one! 
The beach is located in the midst of a nice neighborhood with beautiful houses and it has its own parking lot above the beach. There are steps leading down to a concrete pavilion and another smaller wooden walkway down to the shore. The beach from what I've seen from reviews and our own experience, seems to be a little hidden gem which keeps this spot secluded and the visitors to smaller amount. I'm a nature girl who likes to enjoy the scenery in a more peaceful environment. 
The real star of the show was the view - OMGoodness the view!!!  From one side of the shore, you can see cliffs, foliage and the beautiful houses built on top. In the middle, you can look out on the water and the outline of the mountains cutting through the skyline. Then on the other end are more cliffs and a picturesque view of the Golden Gate Bridge. The whole scene is like straight from a postcard. It was an absolutely gorgeous view and we were so happy to have found it.
author: Lael M.

description:
Second time in a year an old guy has aggressively come up to me to tell me they are a park ranger and if I don't leave w/ my support dog I'll be arrested. Neither would tell me their name or badge number. I'm not sure if these are actual public servants or not but if they are their demeanor and lack of professionalism embarrasses the city. 

This is probably the nicest beach in the city.
author: Eli M.

description:
China Beach is tucked away in the affluent neighborhood of San Francisco.

Its a trek to get to but well worth it.

The views of the Golden Gate Bridge are second to none.

Parking is sparse so get here early.

There is currently construction taking place and the restrooms are not open.  They have a few port a potties available. 

It is also a great place to sit, relax have a picnic or even go fishing.

Can't wait to visit again when back in the Bay Area.
author: Arnel D.

description:
It's totally uncool to bring your fake service dog here.  To be clear, neither emotional nor support dogs are Service Dogs.  You know this for sure.  Right!  If not, here's the drill:  The official definition of a service dog is that it's an animal trained to do particular tasks for a person with a physical or mental disability. These tasks must be connected to how the person is able to function. The service dog works to compound, support and assist these activities or mitigate the person's impairment.

Any other nonsense from you entitled creeps is BULLSHIT.
author: Tony K.

description: It was a good little place to go and just relax I like it nice place to come hang out and eat something small
author: Rafael A.

description:
Great little beach tucked away in the beautiful Sea Cliff neighborhood. I try to go home to the city every month or so and each time I go back, I try to get a different vantage point of my beloved Golden Gate Bridge. China Beach provides that and then some. 

There is a small parking lot located at the entrance above China Beach. There are clearly marked spaces and you'll notice the mansion behind you in a peach/pink color is probably the Ambassador to Switzerland's residence with the Swiss flag flying in the wind... What a view that household must have every morning! There is also a monument at the entrance that commemorates China Beach as a campsite that many Chinese fisherman used during the Gold Rush. So you get a little history and a view to match it.

You make your way down to the beach via 2 routes. The wide steps that are covered in sand or the longer paved path. Either way, it will get you to the bottom. You will see a structure whose inside is no longer open to the public along with its restrooms. But there are 2 bigger sized port-a-potty units near the base of the big set of stairs. I had to use one of them and to my surprise, it was SUPER clean. I think it had gotten changed out/cleaned up that morning. Either way, I was extremely grateful... You can go onto the roof level of the structure and that provides a bird's eye view of the beach. 

Make your way down some more stairs and you''re on the sand. To the right is the Golden Gate Bridge in the distance. It looks great on a clear day or on a foggy day. It's just a gem of a beach. Super peaceful with no one really out on the day we went. It was a little foggy and misty. Just the way I like it. There was a dad with his 2 kids playing on the sand near the stairs but they soon left. We had the beach all to ourselves. I took so many photos. Couldnt help it... I truly enjoy being a tourist at home. China Beach is one of those places I can go back to over and over again.
author: Chuck D.

description: China beach is a hidden gem in SF. Located in the Seacliff area of Richmond, this beach is less popular than it's neighbor, Baker Beach. Also less known then the super crowded Ocean Beach. Great views of the Golden Gate Bridge and beautiful cliff sides give this beach a very picturesque vibe. Today we were able to see dolphins as well as a brave otter who came fairly close to shore, to the crowds amusement. This is also a great place to stop by if you are hiking around Lands End.
author: Sara K.

description: Arrive by car or bus (yes, no tour buses!). Great to be able to walk down to the beach and have a clear vie of GG Bridge. Steps down are pretty easy. Love being able to find a quieter spot with awesome views.
author: Clarence E.

description:
Peaceful, quiet, and definitely a hidden gem in San Francisco. Across from Robin Williams' old home (RIP), the beach seems fairly unknown. This is great as it'd be a wonderful spot to relax on the sand, listening to the waves. 

The view is as gorgeous as that of Baker Beach. The beach is also much cleaner with plentiful parking in its small lot. There is a sharp turn that's easy to miss if you are following Google maps, so beware! I'll be back fairly soon to unwind after a long week!
author: Kristi T.

description: Really beautiful beach especially at sunset and the view of the bay bridge! One of my favorite beaches of San Francisco.
author: Gabrielle D.

description: Beautiful hidden beach & near eagles point. I was coming from a nearby brewery & needed to use restroom. Unfortunately restrooms were closed! Seriously?! Now what? Pee on myself or pee in a hidden way. I peed at eagles point ( 0.5mi away)  & hid behind a tree! Anyways, absolute great views of golden gate!
author: Rubby R.

description:
Finally checked out this beach. Cannot believe I waited this long.  This is now another of my favorite  go to places in San Francisco.   Really beautiful, both the beach and the drive through the Presidio to get there. 

 Good mix of people, both singles and families picnics, playing ball, looking for sea shells, walking along the waves, generally enjoying the day.  Very safe, kicked back atmosphere.  Noticed a lot of guitar playing, which was another fun add to this beach.  

Parking is pretty easy. 

There are public  restrooms but they were closed on the Sunday afternoon we were there.  The porta potties were unfortunately gross. The only complaint. ( Note....Women and parents: finding another restroom open to the public anywhere in SF is difficult at best.  Be aware)   

This is a dog friendly beach and my Dog With Very High Standards had a happy afternoon exploring.  

Access to viewing the beach is easy...there is a sloping walkway to a viewing level building.  Actually getting down to the beach  does require about 25 or so steps. Beautiful sand, waves, view of the Golden Gate Bridge and mostly protected from winds so well worth it. Highly recommend!
author: Anna G.

description:
Located in SF's Sea Cliff neighborhood, China Beach boasts gorgeous views of the Marin Headlands and the Golden Gate Bridge. 

This is our special little cove tucked away between Land's End to the west and Baker Beach to the east. 

The beach is accessible two ways from the parking lot - via a paved accessible path or a steep stairway.

Before you descend to the cove, you'll find a memorial to the Chinese fishermen and early residents who camped and anchored here during the Gold Rush.

Facilities with restrooms and cold water showers are available from sunrise to sunset for everyone's convenience.

Although the frigid temps keep us out of the water most months, we love this family-friendly spot to lay out and a have a picnic with our children. As with most SF beaches, there are *no lifeguards on duty.*

If you don't want to lay out on the sand, you can sunbathe atop the small deck located above the lifeguard equipment pick-up station where it's less windy.

Fires and glass containers are not allowed on the beach, however there are grills and a small picnic area available on a first-come, first-served basis above beach level. 

Note: China Beach is one of two San Francisco beaches that does NOT permit dogs, unless it is a service animal (Marshall Beach is the other location).

Pro-Tips:
* Check out the tide charts (via your favorite free app / search engine) and plan a low-tide walk from China Beach to Baker Beach. You'll find plenty of starfish, anemones, and mussels clinging to the rocky cliff crevices - but please don't make souvenirs of the marine life. 

* "Leave No Trace": kindly take with you what you brought down to the beach. Trash receptacles are available near the restrooms and in the parking lot. Let's minimize our impact and Leave No Trace of our visits to wilderness, parks and beaches. Help protect precious natural and cultural resources and preserve the experience for you and for future visitors. 

To learn more about the "Leave No Trace" program by the National Park Service, visit nps.gov
author: Geminyna J.

description:
I love this hidden gem of a beach! The steep steps are a perfect alfresco stair master. The view of the Golden Gate Bridge is always breathtaking- even on a foggy day, the air is crisp and exhilarating. Aside from the occasional fisherman or two, you might just have the whole beach to yourself. 
There are lovely starfish when the tide goes out too. Plenty of parking if you're into that kind of thing...:-)
author: Carole B.

description:
I LOVE how this beach is secluded! Every time I passed this area down I always thought it was Baker Beach.

There's ample parking so you don't have to worry about driving around.

Make sure to grab a jacket too because it may be cold.

There's a sign just before you start going down towards the beach explaining why it was called China Beach and what it was used for.

The sand beneath your feet felt amazing and relaxing! The view of the Golden Gate Bridge was also breath-taking.

If you have to go to a beach in San Francisco, make sure to check this beach out!
author: Aj C.

description:
Beach goer beware, there is a once studly man who poses as a park service ranger.  His uniform of choice is a grungy old park service hat and tight speedos, nicely displaying an uncomfortably visible package (meow).  His leathery tanned skin shows the resemblance of what had to be some glorious poon hound days.  Unfortunately those times were several decades ago and now he just creeps around China Beach, posing as an elder creep, oogling innocent women.  

I can't wait for the next time I get to see those filled out short shorts.
author: Patty C.

description:
Not as big as Baker Beach. And the nudes aren't here. China Beach is pretty tranquil, save for the rare hot SF day when everyone heads to the beach.

Clear view of the Golden Gate bridge. Some people come fishing. And there are some good big rocks to climb. Limited parking in the small lot, so you may have to wander for street parking.
author: Joanna L.

description: This was the third and last beach we went to on our trip.  I think this was my favorite.  The sand was very soft and the kids loved playing in it.  Wasn't crowded at all.  It's a steep walk down from the road.  You can stay on the service road provided or walk down some steps.  The views were so beautiful too.  I would highly recommend this beach!
author: Jenn M.

description:
I love China Beach. 

If you are visiting San Francisco or you live in San Francisco and you wanna go out on a nice day, China Beach is one of the nice destinations to stop by.

Here is a suggestion: 
- grab coffee from the Presidio
- stop by China beach to take pictures of the Golden Gate Bridge
- then go to the Legion of honor. 

You won't regret it.
author: Ahmad A.

description: This place is not a beach. It's the size of a Safeway with dark sand. If you are claustrophobic don't bother. If you seek serenity and zen don't bother.
author: Angel Y.

description: China Beach is my kind of jam. Small, quiet, and peaceful. A great place to sit back and enjoy the ocean waves - maybe listen to some music and contemplate life. There are usually a few surfers at China beach, along with a small crowd lounging around in the sand. Generally, it isn't too busy. You may see some kids playing in the sand, or a group of bros drinking beer, but my experiences at China Beach have usually been pleasant, and fairly quiet.
author: Andrew L.

description: Nice place. It's very scenic. You can also take pictures with the Golden Gate Bridge in your background too.
author: Theresa S.

description: WOW, awesome views with the Golden Gate Bridge right behind. The water was cold since we went in September but we enjoyed hanging out.
author: Grace F.

description: One of the nicest views of the Golden Gate Bridge from San Francisco !!!
author: Rick S.

description:
Great vista point to view Golden Gate Bridge. Long and smooth beach. Quite enjoyable even in cool February. There are numerous happy doggies. All well behaved and nicely trained.
Many international tourists too. It is a very popular  beach.
author: Pno E.

description: I am new to this beach and i was wondering if were able to swimm in it it looks beautiful and from the pictuers it looks like people love going there and enjoy it there i just wanna know if we can swimm there
author: Perla P.

description: Beautiful view of the bridge even on a foggy day. Lots of parking above the beach and a short trip down stairs (or a ramp) to reach the shore.
author: Melissa W.

description: Visited this Beach for the 1st time. Dad would come here a kid. It could use some love (burnt structure-- no bathrooms besides the porta-potty that had been full for way to long) but it was a nice small beach that my 3 yr. old could let loose on. Its a little bit of a hike down to the beach from where you park, but we enjoy adventure. Found many shells, driftwood and rocks to add to our collection at home.
author: whitney s.

description: Today as I was sitting there waiting for a fish to bite a gentleman walking on the beach was annoyed he had to walk around my line and asked me to move closer to the water.  I could tell he wasn't trying to be rude but he was frustrated saying we (fisherman) were effectively cutting the beach in half by having our lines out.  I explained that the tide was receding and about 20min ago my rod was very close to the wave breaks but id be happy to move it closer to the water to accommodate him. Then he asked why there were so many fisherman here over the past few weeks and I told him i thought it was bc crabbing season had opened in November.  Then as I was leaving the beach I saw the writing in stone explaining that China beach was historically a fishing cove where Chinese fisherman would fish heavily to support the developing economy of the young city... therefore fisherman should not be seen as a nuisance but as an icon to this wonderful San Francisco beach.  Also the Fishing and crabbing is always good here at China beach SF and I'm thankful for every opportunity to take part in that iconic tradition.
author: Dan O.

description:
Very, very chill beach.

This beach is located about 1.5 miles away from Ocean beach and it's around a lot of residential zones. If you set it on your gps, it should be fairly easy to go here. There is also a small parking lot for this beach so parking is very easy to do. 

If anything, this beach is mostly just for relaxing and chilling. There's a sign that says no glass and no fires which put a damp on my friends' idea of having a bonfire, but we still had fun. Once you park your car, you have to walk down steps in order to get down to the beach. And there are about 3 tables to the right side along with a grill if you ever want to do a picnic or something. And there are bathrooms! Yay! 

The beach itself is nice. The sand is soft and there's not a whole lot of rocks so walking on your bare feet isn't a pain. The beach is a bit small, but it's cozy looking and I'm guessing not a lot of people know about it so it wasn't crowded. There's also a large rock off to the left side right behind a wall. I went on top of it with a friend and my boyfriend and it gave us a great view of the beach altogether.

Overall, decent beach. Would definitely come back just to chill.
author: Venus L.

description:
Tucked between Lands End and Baker Beach, this sheltered beach features a picnic area, sunbathing, good play spots for children, and spectacular views of the Marin Headlands and Golden Gate.

The facilities look antiquated and are very rusty. A bunch of graffiti is on all the concrete walls, but it gives the beach its unique character. The surrounding Sea Cliff neighborhood is beautiful and part of the experiences. 

Access to the beach is via a paved drive or stairway down from the parking lot to water level.

Above beach level, grills and a picnic area are available on a first-come, first-served basis. 

Restrooms and cold water showers are open sunrise to sunset.

Take a low-tide walk from China Beach to Baker Beach and find starfish, anemones, and mussels clinging to the rocky crevices of the cliffs.

Legend has it that local residents named China Beach for the Chinese fishermen who, long ago, anchored their junks in the cove and camped on the beach. You can see a monument to these early residents at the trailhead near the parking area at the end of Sea Cliff Avenue.

Please note:

No pets, fires, and glass containers are allowed.

No lifeguards are on duty. Due to unpredictable surf conditions, swimming is not recommended.
author: David S.

description: It's a small quaint beach and somewhat private from the main road.  Unless you know about it, there aren't any signs directing other than "public beach".  It's tucked away in the lavish Sea Cliff neighborhood amongst some stately looking homes.   The waves are a bit stronger here with signs giving warning of past drownings.  People still swim in the water anyways.  A distant view of the golden gate bridge can be seen from afar. This is a nice little escape during the week when there are the least amount of beach-goers.  Unfortunately, you only have access to a porta-potty.  If it's anything like the one on Baker Beach, I don't recommend it.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
Amazing, rustic beach with great views.  It's pretty awesome that areas like this in super high end neighborhoods are protected and available for the public.  We took a nice little morning walk to here from where we were staying in the Richmond District.  We hung out and climbed on the rocks a bit and just took in the natural beauty for a good long while.

We were here on a Monday morning.  It wasn't crowded at all.  Hardly anyone else was there.  There was a small group of four seasoned swimmers that regularly swim here.  We had a really nice chat with one of them who happened to be a fourth generation San Franciscan.
author: Terence D.

description:
This is literally the worst beach I have ever visited in my whole life. Then again I've mostly lived on the California Coast so I'm sure there is worse out there. My friends and I were walking along the Lands End Trail and needed to stop to use the restroom. We came to China Beach (where we were greeted with NO DOGS ALLOWED signs) and hunted around the dilapidated building parked in the middle of the beach. Perhaps this is an ancient historical artifact. 

At any rate, there is trash everywhere and it's all just very unappealing an dirty. Someone setup a cute and colorful little reception at the benches nearby. That was the only nice thing about the whole place. Oh and there is a little parking lot behind the ratchet looking building... nice! Otherwise, I'm never coming back!!
author: Stefanie C.

description: We were hiking the Lands End Trail and came here for a rest.  Fantastic views,  nice breeze,  few people.  The bathhouse or building was being renovated,  which it badly needs.  It was closed and port-o-potties were there.  It is in the middle of a luxury neighborhood,  so the environment is nice.
author: J L.

description: Loved it, the water was cold since it was September, but the view was gorgeous. The Golden Gate Bridge was right behind. It wasn't crowded compared to other beaches (e.g. Ocean Beach).
author: Grace F.

description:
Bring everything: food, booze, swim gear, and NO DOGS.  Read the clues when you enter.  And comply accordingly.  Otherwise you'll be interdicted when you get to the beach where Rangers have fun dealing with your foolishness and stupidity. That's right.





















r
author: Nate R.

description:
Quickie:
+ Secluded, romantic, must-see hidden gem of a seaside beach 
+ Nice view from the side of the Golden Gate Bridge
+ Date spottttt

---

Location/Parking:
There is a lot you can park in and then you have to walk down a flight of stairs or down the inclined road. From there it's just you and the sand flanked by some rocky cliffs with the Golden Gate Bridge on the far right in the background. This place looked gorgeous at sunset and there was a proposal being set up as we were leaving (very romantic-esque). It wasn't crowded that Friday evening so it'd make a good date spot.

Verdict:
If I'm back in the area, would definitely include this on my list of brief stops around sunset. What a view.
author: Amy H.

description: My favorite beach in the city! One of SF's hidden gems. Gorgeous view of the Golden Gate Bridge. Small and peaceful. It can get kind of crowded on a warm sunny day since it is so small.
author: Angela L.

description:
Of the four beaches in the City, this is my fave.  We don't have many sunny days but when we do, it can't be beat to go to the beach; enjoy the day watching the waves and soaking the rays.

Showers and restroom facilities.  

Great views of the Marin Headlands across the water and of the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Plan to come early because parking can be a nightmare! Street parking in the neighborhood but there IS a tiny parking lot right in front of the stairs of the beach. This is one of the smaller secluded beaches but it has an amazing view of the Golden Gate Bridge. It has bathrooms and there's a building to just tan on if you don't wanna head into the beach area.

Be aware that you have to go down a long flight of stairs to get to the actual beach but it isn't tooo bad!
author: Veronica A.

description:
This is a beautiful beach with a nice view of the Golden Gate Bridge. If you don't feel like rubbing elbows with the nudists at Baker Beach, then make your way here. 

China Beach is fairly secluded and the parking lot is small. Like many of the beaches in the area, there are stairs that lead to the sandy beach. I came here for a photo shoot, so I didn't explore too much, but I was very satisfied with how the photos turned out.

I no longer live in San Francisco, however, I'm sure I'll be back someday to visit. Until then, I have the photos to remind me of how I left my heart in San Francisco.
author: Annette C.

description: My favorite beach to hang out in SF. I used to live in the area a couple of years ago and walked here randomly and realized what a gem this place was. It's a great place to relax and unwind at. It also has a great view of the golden gate which is a great place to take pictures at as well. I love it here!
author: Bhavisha P.

description:
As my last view of the SF Golden Gate Bridge before departure home, this was a perfect spot to sit and enjoy the sunset before heading to the airport. 

I was happy to have found this spot - nestled near so many beautiful homes. The windy walk was well worth the last few mins of SF time I had here. What a great way to end a road trip that started out from LAX - down the PCH! Glad to finally have made it!
author: Lauren B.

description:
No dogs allowed!

We were greeted by a rude man who identified himself as a government worker and told us dogs were not allowed. This was our first time at China Beach so was unaware of this law so we were happy to leave. As we turned around to leave he stayed in our faces and kept addressing how we breeched the beach with our dog and should really know how to read signs.

A simple "no dogs are allowed" would have been enough but his extra efforts to prove a point was what really annoyed us. 
 
Besides that, pretty quiet beach and not crowed at all.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
The biggest struggle when it comes to going to any beach is parking. Finding parking near enough to this beach can be a bitch if you weren't lucky to make it into the parking lot right off the staircase down to the beach. Your best bet is to just drive around the residential area just a little ways up from that small parking lot. Good luck.

The beach itself is pretty small, especially on a super nice day. Small in the sense that's it's best to go in a group no larger than 5-6.
author: Shawn B.

description:
My partner took me hear after supposedly doing some research and hearing that Bill Murray has a house around here, but after a quick Google search and the fact that I went here and Bill didn't immediately feel my presence and come out to whisper sweet things to me tells me that those realty rumor are just that... but I guess it was still a nice beach to check out. 

+ There's parking. 

+ Views. Yeah, there's that. 

+ My partner and I were the only ones here, and that was on a weekend day no less. So, nice if you are normal person who doesn't like to be hounded by screaming kids and hoards of tourist.

+ It's small for beach, but big enough that if there had been 3 other couples there we wouldn't have felt obligated to acknowledge them with a 'hey' or upwards head nod. 

+ Lots of stairs. I guess if you're from SF it's just regular, but if you're from a less active part of the country (Midwest, Suburbia, USA) like lazy ole me, you might not notice the stairs on the way down to the beach, but when you're working your way back up- oh boy! Just trying to hold back from heaving and hurling. #HomerSimpsonProblems
author: Candice G.

description:
I swung by here with my fiance last weekend to see if we could potentially have our engagement photos taken here. The verdict is ... absolutely not! There is nothing special about this to us. The stretch of beach is small. It is cold as hell. There is not much going on for the place other than 
1- that it is a place of historical significance 
2- there is a view of the Golden Gate Bridge 
3- has a bathroom.
Yea I get it - there's a view of the Golden Gate Bridge from the beach and you might fancy that if you are a tourist; however there are SO many better stretches of beach in SF with breath taking views. I'd much rather go to the beach by Chrissy Field (so much fun for dog watching) and Mile Rock Beach on the Lands End trail. Note however, Mile Rock Beach doesn't really have sand to walk on, rather rocks.
author: Michelle T.

description: This is a response to Eli M. There is an official park policy and clear signs that allow only service dogs at China Beach, which, by the way, is the only place in San Francisco where dogs are not allowed. The beach is small and there are families with infants so it makes sense that dogs are not permitted. Rules are in place for a reason, even if we don't like them because they are not convenient for us.... You can always walk five minutes and take your dog to Baker Beach.
author: Roberto S.

description:
China beach is one of my favorite place to take photos. It is unique and can take shots with the sunset.

You also can take a look of other locations backer beach for example.
http://www.pashadelic.com/photos/97331
author: Kenji Y.

description:
Nice neighborhood and a great view of the golden gate bridge. 
Parking is limited and at high tide the beach area is small.
I would go here for the view and a quick swim but nothing more than that. 
You really cannot lounge on this beach due to the small size of it.
author: Scott M.

description: Great small beach, with a view of the pacific and the golden gate. Would highly recommend if you are looking for a good view or a peaceful stop
author: Nick H.

description: Nice secluded beach between Lands End and Baker Beach.  Parking is crowded on weekends. We walked over from Lands End.
author: Linda L.

description: We came on such a beautiful day. There's quite a few people on this small beach. If you're lucky, get the small beach area to the left. It's a little more secluded and the cliffs help shield you from the sun. The waves are far too strong for swimming. It felt so nice to dip your feet in the water. You also have a great view of the SF bridge, great for pictures. Loved this place. Will definitely come back to visit.
author: Cindy C.

description:
Finally got a chance to explore China Beach with my boyfriend on our anniversary. Heading down the beach was an adventure only because there were about 50 steps to walk in order to get to the site. We brought food in hopes there would be a place to eat, and there was! A few benches/tables scattered around the beach. It was VERY scenic and enjoyable. If you're looking for a relaxing place where you can see the Golden Gate Bridge and beautiful houses..this is the place! Even driving to the beach was great! Although we came on a day where it wasn't so busy, we can assume that many people like to go surfing there. 

We found several sea critters scattered along the beach and we climbed on some reachable cliffs just to get an even better view of the ocean. Love it!
author: Michelle S.

description:
This review is more for the staff that works here rather than the beach itself. I mistakenly brought my small dog not knowing it was a "no dogs and crying babies" (according the staff there) beach. We were greeted by an unpleasant man who claimed "to be with the park service" who said we had to leave immediately since we had a dog. This man wasn't wearing any govt ID or uniform btw. I had no problem leaving bc I legitimately made a mistake not knowing dogs weren't allowed but what was annoying was his aggressive tone. As we were leaving he was extremely rude saying "we had to leave the exact same way we just came" and "should spend time familiarizing ourselves with the signs." I told him it was an honest mistake and he proceeded to tell me to "chill." Super weird, unprofessional, and aggressive. Merry Christmas to all, eh? 

The city should know about this guy and if he really does work with SF Park and Rec they should reevaluate the type of people they hire.
author: Sarah G.

description: China beach. Beautiful. The mist around sunset was breathtaking. Guess how many Chinese people I met here. Zero. All f*cking white people.
author: Steve Y.

description:
I love China Beach.  

It is a great place to take pictures of the bridge, and there are a few rocks to climb on.  It's never too crowded there, but I have seen a lot of surfers and a few body boarders towards the left of the beach, sometimes the waves are huuuuge!

There are 100 stairs to walk up and down to the beach, or there is a road you can walk up and down as well.
author: Jill B.

description:
This is a wonderful non-touristy beach and vista spot for the Golden Gate bridge. 

Our friends invited us to China Beach for a BBQ, but we had never been to China Beach before. After finding the perfect parking spot, we realized we accidentally had arrived at Baker Beach --oops! We've been there, and it's definitely not China Beach. 

Go a little further down the road, and you'll actually end up at a small parking lot at the top of China Beach. Parking is tough over here! Even though the beach was fairly empty, we waited awhile for a spot! Try street parking over the lot if it's a warm weekend.

Walk down the steps, and take in the beauty! There's beautiful rocks to climb, a small cove, and a small sandy beach. There's plenty of sand to build sandcastles, and also a dry sandy area to sunbathe. There's a gorgeous view of the Golden Gate bridge as well. Our friends nabbed a picnic table with perfect views. There's BBQ's apparently here too! Our picnic area had grass too, so we didn't even have to get sandy!

Plenty of people picnic on top of the giant rock, but watching people climb up there with beach chairs and coolers is nerve-wrecking, but humorous. We didn't any spills thank goodness!

This also seems to be the wedding picture photo-op spot! I would think engagement photos would be nice here, but we saw a bride & groom taking photos here and the bride was in her full wedding gown! The dress must have been so damaged after the shoot (she was even in the water!), so I'm guessing it was post-wedding, but still...what a way to ruin a dress!
author: Rebecca G.

description:
a very cozy beach in a cove with excellent views of the Golden Gate Bridge , looks like a nice place for a picnic at the beach

it's like a hidden gem out of the way place to go enjoy a sunny day and relax or do some fishing

it's a small area so it could get a little crowded especially on a nice sunny day

also because of the interesting California Gold Rush era history:

Legend has it that local residents named China Beach for the Chinese fishermen who, long ago, anchored their junks in the cove and camped on the beach. You can see a monument to these early residents at the trailhead near the parking area at the end of Sea Cliff Avenue.
author: Mr Bolo B.

description:
BEAUTIFUL.

I came here around 4:45pm on a Saturday night just so my boyfriend and I could watch the sunset AND view the Golden Gate Bridge! On the way there, you'll pass gorgeous houses. Parking is free! You'll be led down a long flight of stairs. It's a tiny beach, but it's good because you feel somewhat cozy and private. The sand wasn't soft... I'm not sure if the water goes all the way to the ledge or if it was the weather. We stood right over the balcony thing. You can't actually see the sun from this side, but it's good enough. Otherwise, you would have to actually cross the bridge, which may seem like a hassle and run into traffic. My boyfriend and I were both pleased to end our 5 year anniversary with an amazing view!
author: Alice H.

description:
Perhaps not as interesting as Baker Beach, but way, way better than Ocean Beach.
BUT, I saw a KGB-type harassing some people about this and that. The Golden Gate National Parks Conservancy  seems to take themselves too seriously as the so-called "Guardians of the Wilderness", and all they do is act like land-based Sea Shepherds. ( My apologies to those who really care about this beach, as opposed to those who care only about their egos. )
This place was a lot nicer several decades ago.
author: George T.

description:
So this is where everyone is on a hot San Francisco day! I was surprised at how small the beach was but I didn't stop short of marking my spot for a few hours. Sat next to some college kids drinking beer, a girl trying to tan and read a book upside down and my friend, who was pretending to read but probably really fell asleep. I took this time to get off the sand and play in the water. It was freezing yes but it felt so refreshing when I came back to eat my sandwich! As a must, I also took jumping pictures with a clear view of the Golden Gate bridge. My friend and I also tried to climb the rocks on the side but I felt like our old bones kind of failed us. Still got a gorgeous view though! 
Sand is dark brown and the beach was very rocky... meaning there was lots of rocks. Look out for those when you try to play frisbee on the sand or water. We lost ours but I wasn't about to swim for it!
author: Stella Y.

description:
Small and secluded beach away from the city. 

NO DOGS ALLOWED!

It's a pretty scenic drive getting to the beach. You drive through a grip of beautiful big houses. There is limited parking, but once you park it is an easy walk down to the beach where you can enjoy the quiet ocean front. The Golden Gate Bridge is in the backdrop.
author: Danh N.

description: Pretty small beach but perfect to cool down from the 100 degree heat in the north bay.  Baker beach was packed today so we came next door. It's not as crowded & perfect for kids especially on a hot day!
author: My S.

description:
Guess we've come full circle...I remember parking in the lot up above here to eat lunch during high school, back in the day.  On an exceptionally sunny and clear day (unlike the weather we've been having lately), I recently had the pleasure of coming here to eat my lunch.  And what a lunch it was too...my favorite Deli Board sandwich, the Boca on dutch crunch!  Munching on that delicious sandwich at a picnic table down by the beach with an incredible view of the water and bridge, I felt very fortunate indeed.  I know you're not supposed to feed the birds, but I couldn't resist giving them a tiny bit and they really loved my food too.

Always mellow, laid-back feel to the place.  It's not a happening place, just a great place to get away from it all and relax.  Convenient bathrooms too!  Works for me.
author: Roy N.

description:
Sssh....don't tell tourists about this spot. Let's try to keep this beach a local's secret.

Anyhow, what can I say about China Beach that hasn't been said before.
It's simply a piece of paradise in this urban metropolis. 
I love the view of the bridge. And this beach is so much cleaner than the other beaches in the city! And because it's secluded, it's never that crowded. 

I saw dolphins here once, they were swimming so close to the beach! Truly a magnificent sight. 

They have restrooms and showers. Others have said parking is limited, however I've never had to wait for a spot here. 

Oh, and since dogs aren't allowed, no one has to worry about stepping in doo doo.
author: Wanda M.

description: I finally scoped out this spot tucked in between the windy streets of Seacliff. It was a perfect day for running up and down the steps to the beach and getting some great shots of the Golden Gate. Even on the warmer sunny days, it's still quite windy but that blows all the cloudy away for a great view of the Marin Headlands across the water. Less crowded then Bakers and not to far away.
author: Naomi K.

description: Came here for family photos.  Really liked it.  Beautiful views of the Golden Gate and the entrance to the Bay.  Nice little beach.
author: Dylan S.

description:
I got married on China Beach in early October.  It was the most perfect location for the small, intimate, and very private ceremony I had hoped for.  For the time that we were there, there were hardly any other people coming and going.  It really did feel like our very own private beach!

I highly suggest coming here to relax with your friends, partner, or even by yourself.  The views of the Golden Gate and sunset are truly remarkable. 

*If you do get married here, it is recommended to obtain a license.. it's about $225.  Sure, no one may check on you, but it would be horrible if they did and ended up kicking you out*
author: Mai T.

description:
I'm from LA! I got nothing love for the bay area. It's a very beautiful city with some very majestic views. My lady showed me this beach before moving back down to LA. I have to say this is a sick ass beach. 

One thing I'm not used to is how cold it is the bay area. Just a sweater with hoodie wont' work here. You'll need a full on jacket especially with a strong breeze that come through here. It's pretty trippy getting to the beach since you have to walk down a flight of stairs. It's really worth it. 

It's a great place to just go running or have a picnic during the day. It's a sick ass spot. The water is hella clean! Next time when I come up I would want to go fishing in this spot.
author: Gene K.

description:
One of my favorite, quite and peaceful parks in SF that is still a bit of a secret. A lot of people know about China Beach but it certainly isn't nearly as busy as most other parks in the city nor has it been degraded with litter, graffiti and other random damage that comes along with being a public park in a big city. I come here for the peace and quiet to rest, relax and think while taking in the scenery. Many times you come here and all you can hear are the birds and waves coming in and hitting the sand. 

I usually bring my dog here but I'm actually not sure if they're allowed or not. I haven't seen any signs that prohibit dogs nor has anyone ever given me any trouble about having him and he sure loves to run on the beach. I imagine many of you can do the same as I do and not have a problem so long as you clean up after your 4-legged friend.
author: Elaine M.

description:
Bring a jacket.

Of course, this is San Francisco.. always bring a jacket!!!

Parking was easy.. the sand was warm.. the gusty winds were unbearable.. the scenery/view was just lovely.. you'll see people sunbathing (though there were no sun!), people walking, people in the water, dogs running around, people going surfing, kites in the sky.. 

Overall this is a very decent place to come.. if you don't mind the wind.
author: Tram N.

description:
China Beach is nice, but I'm not quite sure I get the hype. It's very small, dogs aren't allowed, the sand is very hard and compressed (not good for bocce ball), and did I mention it's small?

If you make the poor choice to come on a day that other people choose to come on (in other words, all of the days), be prepared to be cozy with other people. 

On the other hand, our most recent visit (early November) was graced with beautiful views of the bridge, a dolphin pod swimming into the Bay, a sea lion (I think?) trailing after a man who was out swimming laps, and the most awkward wedding photoshoot ever. So, maybe it's not my favorite beach in the city, but it's definitely worth the occasional visit.
author: Megan S.

description: This is the newest place for surfers and crabbers to go. Coming out here you see people carrying either fishing gear, surfer board or both down the hill. It is no longer just a public beach where people sat around enjoying the beach and the water.
author: M C.

description: The best beach in SF with amazing views of the golden gate bridge.  This beach is small, somewhat secluded, with very little parking.  Their are a few tables and grass area, not good for large groups.  But a great spot to fish or swim because the current isnt as strong as ocean beach.  If you want some amazing shots of the brdige, this is the place to go!
author: Terence N.

description: Your Match profile says you like long walks on the beach? Don't take your date here. It's small and a walk end to end would take you about 5 minutes. The good news is it's a beautiful non-touristy beach, perfect for when a rare fog-free San Francisco day hits. Not much to do here besides sun yourself and it's nestled in a secluded residential area, but that's also the charm.
author: Jeremy S.

description: China Beach gets my vote for best hidden San Francisco GEM
author: Bumble B.

description:
Went there today for the very first time with my son and our dog. Nice beach.  Great place to get some culture in. 

The stars are taken away because of this:
The happy moment was RUINED by an older gentleman who was neither a park ranger or a policeman. 
There was an ass who was at the gates. I took our dog a couples steps down so I can see my son and husband walk on the beach. 
RUDE RUDE MAN. Could have just said don't do it next time but proceeded to be an a$$. The person who he was speaking to decided to go back across the street in embarrasment. He proceeded to lecture me on 'as an adult, I should teach to follow the rules.' Wow. Guess he never jay walked or anything else right. Such a boyscout.
author: Heidi C.

description:
Views to take in....Rocks to climb...Waves to soothe. 

Go to China Beach.
author: Jocelyn B.

description:
Been coming here for years, I have always liked this beach (tho I never sat on the beach), the drive through the neighborhood, and a go-to place when I need to pee with restrooms at the bottom of the stairs.

The view is spectacular, this is a stop on my SF Tour either by car or bicycle.
author: qirk z.

description:
SF has so many beautiful places to explore, and China Beach is definitely one of them.  It's a cute little neighborhood beach that offers magnificant views of the Golden Gate Bridge, hiking trails and a lil more privacy than other beaches in the area might... at least on the day we were there.  It's a photographers dream with the views of the bridge though.. they were stunning.  Even my amateur pics looked good!

Only bummer was that there are no dogs allowed.  -1 star.

Might see ya there!
author: Susan D.

description: This is absolutely one of my most favorite places in all of the San Francisco Bay Area.  It's secluded and not very many tourists know of it but it has one of the best views of the Golden Gate Bridge. I usually come here to relax and enjoy the ocean's breeze on a hot day or bring my guitar to play on the beach. Even when it's cold and cloudy, there's something serene about it. In my opinion, I think it's one of the most romantic places in San Francisco because its like having a beach to yourself (or with that special someone). There's a long walk to get down to the beach but once you're there, it's like paradise.
author: Justin C.

description: So, so, so beautiful!! Incredible views of the Golden Gate Bridge and the beach was practically empty. It felt like walking on a private beach. The water is of course too cold to swim in, but take your shoes off and enjoy the view. The only reason I give it 4 stars is because it is a little dirty. But still recommend for locals and tourists alike.
author: Zak C.

description:
They call this place China Beach because it has sand. Bring a towel if you want to dry off after you go in the water. If not, you may have to wait for the air to dry you.

We're lucky to have air (and they have plenty of it at China Beach). You could use it to dry off if you want to, but I would advise against it on the grounds of discomfort.

If air drying is necessary, I recommend a shaking your hair out as you have likely seen done by canines. Wet hair is likely to keep you colder for a longer period of time.

Sand? Check. Air? Check. Water?

Do they have water there?
Yes.

Can you bring a burrito to the beach?
No. There is a strict no burrito policy. Luckily, there is a parking lot above China Beach where you can consume your burrito prior to beach activity (sand-diving, funnoodling, transcendental meditation, making your own candles, etc.).

You should bring a camera just in case you need to take a picture of an interesting hat and want to get a similar one. 

"No matter what you do, believe in yourself."-Aristotle
author: Ryan L.

description:
Wait.....what?  There is a hidden gem of a beach in SF right in the Sea Cliff neighborhood that I've never even heard of and I've been living in and around SF for 12 years??!!!
How could I have missed this?

I was figuring out an itinerary for some cool things to do while my parents were out visiting since they have already hit most of the usual spots and I came across this little gem.  Boy am I glad I did.  It was a nice bonus to take some visitors to a surprisingly beautiful spot that I hadn't even experienced before.  Too bad we hit a foggy day, but I want to come back when the weather is perfect and have a little picnic on the beach.  It's really secluded and there is actually a small patch of beach area to set up a blanket and enjoy the waves.

Gotta love SF, it just keeps getting better and better the longer I live here!!
author: Bethany D.

description: Much less crowded than Baker Beach. Still great view of bridge. Hard to find parking, but we lucked out. Also great to watch sunset
author: Dory W.

description:
Another amazing place! While people flock to Ocean Beach, just north will get you to a few amazing beaches, one being China Beach.

Great views for photography and just to take in the ocean.
author: Roger A.

description: Amazing.  I've been here a couple times, and every time there's maybe 5 people max who are there.  It feels like one of SF's best kept secrets.  The view of the Golden Gate Bridge is incredible, and this is definitely a place to get away from it all.
author: Mel G.

description:
Who knew this place existed? Well apparently at least 60 other yelpers out there that reviewed it!

The fiance and I took some pictures here for our engagement shoot and we felt like we were on our own private beach :)

Great background view of the Golden Gate Bridge...
author: Helen Y.

description: Discovered this during my Nike Women's Marathon run...what a gem!
author: Esther Y.

description:
If it weren't for the fact that it's always foggy, windy, and cold, this would really be something.  If you're able to find a nice day in Seacliff, you'll find this small sandy beach surrounded by rock cliffs to be a real gem.  You can get down to the beach from the limited parking above on a driveway that traverses down or on the stairs.  

Big sign warning you that people have drowned and died here.  Big granite monument memorializing the Chinese fishermen who used to use this beach over a hundred years ago.  The monument was donated by the family that owns Henry's Hunan restaurant.
author: Doctor G.

description: Really nice beach, in my opinion it's better and way cleaner than ocean beach. But this beach is kinda small. They have decent bathrooms that are big enough for you to change & a tanning spot up on top. Also there are tables and a place for rinsing off.
author: Sally L.

description: Who doesn't want a beautiful view of the bay and the Golden Gate Bridge?? Very clean beach, got good parking, and best of all view of the Bridge.  When I came here I saw a older man just roaming around the beach naked! So if your going to bring your kids here just look out! Lol other than that the most beautiful beach! Love China Beach!
author: Alexis G.

description:
First we should establish that this isn't a pretty beach. It has an old concrete structure that is a lifeguard station, chain link fences blocking view from the parking lot, and oil/ash in the sand.

However, this is my favorite beach to go to in SF. It's generally pretty quiet, the views are nice, and there's no nudists (I'm talking to you, Baker Beach).

This past week I took the 2 mile walk down there and sat and watched the sun set. I'm usually not patient enough to sit somewhere for so long, but this place has a charming effect that I haven't yet experienced in any of the other parks and beaches in the city, as good as they are.

The cats that come here are verry friendly and they'll act as if they've known you for years. They're seriously part of the beach, so say hi when you see one of them. And remember the best way to get a cat to trust approaching you is to crouch and hold your finger out so they can sniff you :)

-The Future Old Cat Man
author: Ryan V.

description:
The BEST beach I've been to since the one in Monterey Bay. It's view is BREATH TAKINGGGG! I'm literally stunned by how gorgeous the beach's landscape was. The most upside for me is the clean environment. Yes there are some little bits of trash near the staircase but it's trash free once you're a few feet away from it. 

This beach is worth every ounce of gas to get there. You won't regret it.
author: Mei X.

description:
DON'T GO HERE,  Head to Bakers - much better people watching there.  I like it when it's not too crowded.

Watching the waves in the rain here is AWESOME. I prefer the view of the beach & bridge.  People are overrated.
author: Athena S.

description:
Best beach in SF! We were at China Beach today and it was just perfect. Not many people know about this beach, which is a shame because it has fantastic views. This beach is in a cove, so it is somewhat more protected than Ocean Beach. But be careful, rip rides can still carry you out to the ocean. 

Also, there's been times at this beach when I've been standing in the water and a wave came up and took 4 inches of sand from under me. So all the sudden I was swimming back to shore when moments before I was wading in 2 feet of water. That's right, I went from 2 feet of water to 6 feet of water in seconds. This is how people drown, so be careful!
author: Mitsi M.

description: A public beach that feels like  private beach. Hardly any people here. There is a ramp for strollers and wheelchairs. Handicap parking available.
author: Mocha G.

description: Great Beach, but no dogs allow. We like to climb the rocks, bask in the sun and enjoy the view.
author: Lucy G.

description:
Crowd control = nice.  It's not too packed here.  

Views = nice

Photos = nice (good place for weddings, engagement, etc pictures...please do not send tourists here!)

Walking = nice, it's not too hilly and the stairs that are there, are actually easily accessible, even though I was limping with a sprained ankle.  :)

Actually looking down at the beach = crap.  Broken tires, and other trash left here.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Beautiful!

A quieter place to sit.

Id like to own property here.

Its a sercret surf spot when the swells are huge and everyplace is unmanageable to paddle out!

Beware.....localism and a pecking order if you decide to surf here!

Not for the faint of heart.

Have an understanding of etiquette and right of way.
author: MacKenzie S.

description: There are some gorgeous views from this beach. Enough said.
author: Amy J.

description:
When Ocean Beach is a little too windy or crowded or if you just want to relax at what seems to be your own private beach, this is the spot to come to.

It's perfectly located for me since I live within walking distance, but more importantly, it's a little bit off the beaten path so it's hardly ever crowded; most city dwellers will go to Baker Beach or OB before they ever come here (if they know it exists).

Which reminds me..there used to be this hottie who would pull up on her Japanese super-cycle, walk down the path in her leather cycle suit, and strip right there on the beach only to unveil the tightest yellow bikini - mmm...that girl was Tee-Tastee! 

Damn, I should make that scene into a Coke commercial or something...
author: Art O.

description:
The reason to go here is because it is slightly hidden and therefore uncrowded. Great views and a place to relax. 

I would always walk down the pathway to the beach and right before turning right down to the sand, I would hop the little brick wall, and climb up the huge rock, which I call Meditation Rock. I would sit there and relax above the beach. The top of the rock is fairly flat. Truly awesome. Best time to do this is mid to late morning when there are even less people there.
author: Ken L.

description:
Oh, China Beach, how do I love thee? Let me count the ways!

1) Location.  As the old real estate axiom says, location, location, location.  And what a location it is. China Beach is a stunning  publicly owned piece of  coastline, located in a cul-de-sac off El Camino Del Mar near 28th Avenue. You can easily ride your bike down Lake Blvd., under the shade of sprawling trees, in the comfort of your own bike lane or take the #1 California bus or #38 or 38L Geary bus to 28th Avenue.   Then head towards the ocean on 28th Avenue.  There is one small sign that points to the 'public beach'.  That's right; one.  If you are driving or riding your bike, you will have to take a sharp U turn at that sign to access the beach, otherwise you too will meander along the  Seacliff Avenue mansions, and never get to the beach.  This is a small beach, a little off the beaten path, and definitely an undiscovered treasure. People who love this beach, love it because it is small,non-touristy, rugged sand, secluded in a lovely neighborhood and a great place to get away from it all. People who dislike it, usually do so for the exact same reasons.

2) Amenities.  Huh? Amenities at a beach you say? Ordinarily, amenities wouldn't be on any list I would make, but these have to be mentioned.  There are public restrooms, showers and lockers!  They are exceedingly well maintained, clean and inviting-(if a public restroom can be inviting, that is.)  There is plenty of parking at the top of the hill and places to lock your bikes.  One note: there are no dogs allowed at this beach.

3) The Views.  There are 105 easy to navigate steps from the trail head to the beach.  Honestly, anyone could traverse these steps with ease, however, if steps are problematic, there is a new concrete lane that winds among the flowers, under the trees to the beach.  The road is not for traffic, but for walkers or bicycles.  From the top to the bottom and beyond, the ocean rumbles and crashes into the rocks, the Golden Gate Bridge stands proudly in the distance and the sheer quiet beauty of it all, is arresting. To the left is a small staircase that is a surfer's break.  I am not a surfer (or swimmer), but I have been told that this is the only place that's really suitable for swimming, if you don't mind cold water and that the waves can be huge. And once again, to mention amenities; there is a small picnic area complete with grills, where you can bar-b-que without a permit, which is ultimately cool.  It's a postcard scene you can't purchase and it's free!  The park closes around 8:30ish p.m.

For more information and photos about China Beach, please visit my blog at The Noise Beneath the Apple.
author: Heather J.

description: I have been here when i was younger and I still go there. I like the breeze and the ocean and the sound of it. I used to play in the water too with my rolled up pants and bare feet. Sometimes I would see little crabs or shells i think on land.
author: Serena Z.

description:
A small but delightful stretch of sand hidden from view.

Small groups of families seem to congregate here.  Off from wealthy SeaCliff Drive, it's got one of those picturesque views of the Golden Gate Bridge & Marin.  Nestled among the cliffs is a small stretch of sandy beach & crashing waves.  Even a sun deck building for the basic facilities & sun worshippers.  Worth the trek for a short respite from City urban life.  

Breathe in and enjoy the crashing waves & clean air.
author: Jen L.

description:
Majestic views, next to Robin Williams' house, and sea lions. What more can you ask for?

It's a good place to have a fire at night. Although, I don't think we were allowed to do that, but I'm not sure. 

Don't jump in the water here. There's rocks under the water line. My friend learned the hard way, trying to swim with the sea lions. I don't suggest trying that either.
author: Charles K.

description: Worth a visit. My wife and I were seeking views of the GG bridge and a coastal trail when we set our sights here. The trail actually starts farther north, but the views were great. This is definitely a place for locals, though we did not feel unwelcome. It was great to scramble up the rocks and take photos of the water and the bridge. OK, perhaps the sunbathers scoffed at us with our cameras, but we didn't notice. The water is very cold, and few were in it, mostly kids. Drinking alcohol is apparently legal here, and many were taking advantage of this. If you're a SF visitor and have the time, bring a towel, a picnic and make a day of it.
author: Bob N.

description: This beach may be smaller and not as well-known in San Francisco as the neighboring Baker Beach or Ocean Beach, but it definitely has its charms. Situated on a dead end street in the lovely Seacliff neighborhood, it provides a beautiful northerly view looking towards the Marin Headlands (and also with the Golden Gate Bridge in sight nearby). One can expect smaller crowds. Also it provides fairly clean shower and restroom facilities. Walking to abd from the parking lot provides an opportunity for a small workout also by going up and down either the sloped path or a fairly steep stairway.
author: H K.

description:
One of those secret places soo many of us never knew about and now that we know about it will make it a regular spot. Absolutely a sweet spot to take pix, have a picnic, BBQ, enjoy some time on the beach, or just relax. Private parking lot so no need for street parking on side streets.

Only drawback of this amazing place is there are like 1000 stairs down to the beach so while getting down is not bad coming up is no joke... I think I needed an inhaler! =) Also, wish they had better ways for handicap or elderly to access the beach since the only road going down is for service vehicles ONLY. You could use the road for wheelchair etc if the dirt stairs wont work but pushing someone down or up that hill would be madness. 

Guys... serious mad romantic points for taking your girl here, I think I got AT LEAST two "get out of jail" points for future use for this visit alone.
author: Mike D.

description: I don't know. A beach isn't supposed to be cold and windy for the most part, but this beach has such a great view. While this is more of a snuggie-on-a-warm-day with your significant other kind of a beach, it still lends itself to a great time of its own kind. There are lots of jagged rocks and the sand tends to be on the rough side and the water is super cold, but this is such a romantic spot, and so peaceful, and on a sunny day, it is warm and breezy and can't be beat!
author: Y K.

description:
I love this beach! I've been coming here since middle school, when we'd use a brisk walk down to the beach and back as our PE for the day. Not only do you get to walk through beautiful Sea Cliff to get there, but also because it's Sea Cliff, tour buses aren't allowed; therefore, you never get more than a car-full of tourists here. 

The beach is small, especially during high tide, but it's wonderfully relaxing and generally peaceful. I often come here in the morning for a quick jog up and down the 80 or so steep steps down to the beach before continuing my walk elsewhere. However, my favorite time to come is at sunset. It can be absolutely magical, particularly if you are the only one on the beach.
author: Katie I.

description:
4.5 stars...

Once you walk (or drive) north of California St you're basically in a neighborhood called Sea Cliff which full of incredibly beautiful houses with beautifully manicured landscaping. Take a left on Sea Cliff Ave and take it to the end where you'll find a small parking lot and the entrance to China Beach. China beached is named such because the cove was used as a campsite for many of the Chinese fisherman who worked around the San Francisco area during the gold rush era. It's a tiny beach but despite its size still manages to have a bathroom/shower facility for the many people to make their way down to the little cove below the cliff of mansions. Unfortunately dogs and fires are not allowed and the fenced off beach is only open during the day. It's not the best beach in San Francisco but it's definitely in one of the best neighborhoods and has a great view of the bridge and is worth walking to if you have the time.
author: Matt E.

description: We stumbled on to this great beach that's tucked away in a great neighborhood near Lincoln Park.  It seems private because it's really not that big and it has a view of the GG Bridge.  We weren't supposed to but we drove all the way down because we are adventurous and daring!  Just one of those fun days where you drive around, find hidden gems and fun things to do!
author: Ruthie V.

description: I love this place! It is very calm & relaxing. It can be difficult trying to find this beach but you just need good directions. Watching the sunset here is wonderful.
author: Reese P.

description:
Love China Beach! Cute, cozy, great view of the GG bridge, romantic and it is just gorgeous when the sun is out! I have never seen it get crowded, so that's a plus as well! I don't think a lot of people know how gorgeous this beach is!;) 
It can get a little windy at times but still worth it! This is my fav. after Ocean Beach!
Go and enjoy a lazy picnicy day w/ your friends, you'll like it!;)
author: C A.

description:
This is one of the most pristine beaches in SF. Amazing views of the GG Bridge and surrounding "mansions": Robin Williams lives up the street and you more than likely will pass his house on the way here. 

Not only are the views breathtaking here but this is also a great place to BBQ or picnic and lay out on the deck in the stark!!!! Make sure if you do this, you apply sunscreen on your balls, etc...
author: Chris B.

description: I love this spot can walk from my apartment. Secluded, not to many people. Has a picnic area, bathrooms. and sundeck on the roof. Can lay out on the beach and see the view of the Golden Gate. Not a lot of people and a nice walk. Beautiful  homes all around, and across the street, the home owner has a Swedish flag blowing in the wind.
author: Susie S.

description:
China Beach is about a half mile off of the beautiful Coastal Trail, and a great way to end a short day hike.

It is also perhaps the only place in San Francisco where it is legitimate to feel actual melancholy. 

There is one craggy rock. When I am here I am usually the only person on the beach. Maybe one other person, also looking a bit "whyfore hath you forsaken me."

In front of the craggy rock, nothing but shock and awe, sublime sublime. The giant blood-colored bridge, the cold foggy bay, and far off, the umm stale promontory of Marin. I always get the urge to swim towards it, which is when I know I am going all Percy Shelly. That's when I go home, back through the unravish'd Coastal Trail.
author: H G.

description:
I've heard of China Beach and seen it on maps, but I've never been there until today.  I should have made more of an effort to go there since I'm Chinese?  It's somewhat hidden in a fairly swanky residential neighborhood and walkable from the Legion of Honor.  The beach area is quite small with one large yellow building with restrooms and cans for recyclables (I half expected to see a Chinese person poking into the trash looking for cans and bottles).  There are a few picnic tables and one outdoor grill.  

It's called China Beach because Chinese fishermen used to have a campsite there.  I'm not sure if the fishing is any good but I did see one fisherman.  

There isn't much to do given the size of the beach.  Of course you should stop to admire the views of the Golden Gate Bridge and the waves crashing onto the shoreline.  It seems to be less crowded than other beaches but I've only been there once so I can't say for sure.  I didn't see many shells in the sand but there were some large rocks and plenty of seagulls.  At first I thought the white circles were sand dollars but they were actually seagull droppings.  Ick!

No pets, fires or glass.  Ample free parking.
author: Lolia S.

description: Good place to snap a few photos and just casually sight see. Pretty historic place but the beach is small. Not alot of people go here and theres a nice building with a sundeck on top and bathrooms for use. Its one of those casual beaches to go to just relax real quick maybe grab a book to read. Not too busy and pretty secluded.
author: Andre W.

description:
If you want to show your date how romantic you can be, this is the place to do it.  

Picture yourself sitting on a huge rock high above the rushing waves, holding her or him tight, protecting them against the cool wind.  To the left you see the beautiful sunset.  To the right, the Golden Gate Bridge.  On a clear night you can point out the constellations.  And if the moon is half to full, the natural, romantic lighting completes the scene.

Absolutely perfect.

PS. Just make sure you really truly like your date, because after this experience, they're yours, and you won't be able to get rid of them.
author: Kerrie L.

description:
I'm a man..and real men don't sit around the beach talking about puppy dogs and ice cream!!!!!!!!

But when there's such an awesome semi secluded beach by your house how can you resist? Don't get me wrong, this isn't Manhattan Beach in Socal where you're going surfing. 

This is a small beach with awesome views of the Golden Gate and the SF Bay entrance. You can see ships go by or just enjoy the sounds of the waves. 

When it's high tide you can climb a rock and it feels like your right in the middle of the ocean. If you got a hour to kill and nothing to do you should stop by.

It's also perfect when i take my dog out http://static.px.yelp.com/photo?id=yM02ylySp_LQpt5v7aoryQ&s=l and enjoying the day with some Ben and Jerry's.
author: Dan T.

description:
My BF and I hiked through the Lands End Trail and the Presidio up to China Beach the other day. I'm so happy we kept going because it was absolutely beautiful there! There is a little picnic area right along the beach, great for kickin back with a group of people, some beers, and some good grub. The best part is the the awesome views! You see the Golden Gate Bridge, even though it was a bit foggy the day we went it was still an awesome view! I can't wait for our friends and family to come visit because this will definitely be a spot we will bring them!
Check out some of the pics we took at China Beach....so pretty!
http://www.sanfrancisconoobs.com/08-03-2009/china-beach-sea-cliff/
author: Casi C.

description: Baker Beach's little sister. More intimate.
author: Inigo M.

description:
I'm as red as the five stars I gave it.  

I burned my legs hella bad.  

I'm emitting heat as we speak....and yes, I do sizzle when you touch me.
author: Jay H.

description:
Wonderful for early morning wading in surf.  Keep an eye out for rip currents;
they are easily spotted.

Ignore the dark-skinned creep that lurks about up on roof of changing and locker
room.
author: Richard D.

description: This is my favorite SF beach. Gorgeous view of the Golden Gate Bridge. The beach is kind of in a cove so it doesn't get too windy on a warm day. The bathrooms have a changing area and showers. It's really peaceful on days when it's not too packed. Aaaaand there's no potential of accidentally getting an eyeful of a guy with his junk hanging out like at Baker Beach (which I have unfortunately experienced first hand)
author: Angelina G.

description:
Amazing views of the pacific and the bay.  And Golden Gate from a far.

I saw a pack of dolphins in the distance, yes dolphins!

Cozy romantic spot to visit.
author: emmy a.

description:
one of the best kept "secret" beaches in San Francisco.  

however, given that 97 yelpers have written reviews about this place before me, then it must not be so secret after all.  I discovered this beach one fine day a couple of years back when wandering around the Presidio area looking at the gorgeous homes.  Since then, I've been back several times and while there seems to always be at least one another person there, it's never been crowded.  There is always parking to be had and the ability to secure a place to park your bum and enjoy the beach the way mother nature intended -- with the sounds of sea gulls and crashing waves.  The water is too cold for me and the sand is nothing like what I would find back home, but the view makes up for those deficiencies.  One of the best things about this beach is what I refer to as the "reverse view" of the golden gate bridge.  Everyone gets the postcard shot from Crissy Fields / Marina / Pier 39 but few get this shot of the GG bridge from the otherside, looking into the bay instead of out to the vast blue younder.  

the only downside to China Beach is that oftentimes it is quite chilly, so don't forget to bundle up or bring a cuddle buddy along for the ride.
author: Catherine A.

description: This is a great spot to bike to. Great views of the ocean near beautiful houses.  However, when I arrived the beach was overrun with chicken hawks. All in speedos no less! After throwing up in my own mouth and gouging out my eyes I was able to enjoy the beach.
author: Roger H.

description:
My friends and I ended up in a limo because we couldn't find a round trip ride to Half Moon Bay. That's another story... 

We had to stop by China Beach so the newlyweds will have a very thick wedding photo album. 

I realized that it's a very hidden beach! Small and uncrowded! I loved it so much that I convinced my friends to come back the next day in a much more comfortable clothes. They loved it too so of course we went.' 

BUT damn the San Francisco weather! It was nice and warm on the wedding day then the next day it got windy and cold! ugh! 

But we did took a lot of great photo!
author: Matt M.

description:
I'm sorry people with all the 5 star reviews.  I really am. I WANTED to give China Beach a stronger rating but I just can't.  
I mean granted I'm a little biased about beaches after having lived in Hawaii the past nine months (on the North Shore of Oahu no less) but still.  The beach is super tiny and has a lot of rocks.  There's also trash which isn't cool at ANY beach.  The chain link fence and ugly concrete lifeguard tower detract from the beautiful views.  I had fun here and even saw a dolphin which makes me feel like the water was cleaner than I thought initially.  Kids were playing and digging up jellyfish that washed up and it seemed a safe family environment but I just wasn't blown away.  I still think it's beautiful and I'll probably visit again a time or two but not even the friendly kitty cats around there make it more than 3 stars for me.
author: Jill D.

description:
This is such a beautiful area....I don't come here to
get in the water...in my 30 years in the Bay area, I have
hardly put a toe in the water....but I do love the spectacular
scenery from this quieter side of San Francisco.  I like
it best on a weekday morning, when there is hardly any
one around - I can just walk and daydream, with my thermos
of hot tea or something more potent, and ponder the mysteries
of life.
author: Carmen H.

description: This place has a smaller stretch of beach than Ocean or even Bakers, but I've gone here one or twice with a group for a picnic. It's got some nice views, but I have come across old discarded glass bottles and trash here sadly.
author: Petra S.

description:
My boyfriend and I spent months up and down the Northern California coast trying to find Star Fish in their natural environment. We had all but given up hope when we happened to find ourselves at China Beach during low tide. I informed my boyfriend I was going to search this one final beach for Star Fish while he took a nap in the sun, which didn't last long, because about 2 minutes after I left that makeshift bed on the sand I hit the jackpot.

There are literally hundreds of Star Fish clinging to the rocks: pink, orange, purple. Absolutely amazing. We've also found if you go to watch the sunset, you can often spot a pod of dolphins jumping just off the coast.

This beach really is a hidden treasure.
author: Carrie W.

description:
You get practically the same view as you do from Baker Beach, sans naked men.  

Stop by for a picturesque view on your way back from Robin Williams' house.
author: Marsha Z.

description: China Beach is one of San Francisco's small, surprisingly undiscovered-by-the-masses beaches.
