It is a cliffside beach, so maybe that discourages the usual potbellies from sauntering down the steep driveway to its sandy shores. It has a very small beach area, but that has never been an issue when we have went there. That's because it's relatively undiscovered and everyone seems to go to Ocean Beach. Meanwhile, China Beach gets overlooked and that's just the way we all like it, since we like to keep the picturesque views of the GGB and crashing waves against the rocks to ourselves.
author: Alex R.

description:
China Beach, thank you for allowing me to be a SF beach bum!

Top 3 reasons to go to China instead of Ocean:
1. The cat with the blue toenails.
2. The stairs down to the water are perfectly spaced out for a non-rest-needing walk back to the car.
3. It will actually be sunny and warm.


Don't love that tourists tend to appear, but hey good on them for knowing about it.
author: Abby M.

description:
I forgot all about this place until today because we visited the Bonita Lighthouse Beach in Marin.  Anyway, this beach is small and dirrrty.

...maybe we went on a bad day... but it's not worth the drive.  It was a waste of gas! minus uno star.
author: Shenni C.

description:
With all the stairs you'd hope there was something a little nicer at the bottom and especially with the Neighberhood it resides in.  The community really should chip in and do something with the structure for bathrooms and picnics at the bottom, California budget cuts be damned.

The upside is the view from the opposite side of Golden Gate, a view seldom seen and oh so worth it!!
author: Jason L.

description: A very peaceful and calm beach.  I'd recommend this beach over Ocean Beach any day.  It's a lot cleaner too.  The only downfall is it's harder to get to than Ocean beach if you take the bus.
author: Karen W.

description:
I went to this beach because Muir beach was packed. The beach is kind of small. There is a good view of the bridge. Also, there is lots of space to tan both on the building roof and the beach. 

The beach is located in a really nice area and there is ample street parking. 

Nice if you're not looking for a very busy place.
author: Andrew Y.

description: Hands down, one of my favorite spots in the City.  Have enjoyed many great workouts at this beach [running loops up the stairs (104 steps), then down the hill and around the building (another 25 stairs) and back up to steep stairs (then reverse that, and do it as many times as you can stand the pain!)]  while enjoying the ocean sounds in the background, and the fresh crisp air.  It is a very grounding and inspiring experience to visit this beach, even if you just plop down on a bench for some quiet time.  It is a peaceful place, and it is rarely loaded with people, and easy to visit.
author: N F.

description:
Been coming here for years.  I adore this beach...it's crazy when the tide is low.  Have you met "Lucky" the cat yet?  He's always around.  

I live down the street.  I may be biased.  But nothing trips me out more than sitting on one of those rocks with my honey watching fins come up in the water.  FINS of what...I'm not sure.  But to me, it's perfectly IMperfect.  It beats Ocean Beach.  All ye locals would agree with me in saying, "I hope those tourists never figure out which street to make that sharp left on."

I'll disregard the one time a few friends and I saw a couple "relating" to one another near the hollowed out rocks (can't really call it a cave).  Um, yeah.  But hey, that's SF for you!
author: Meesh K.

description:
Awesome hidden beach .. rocky walls as opposed to endless sand dunes (think Disney's Little Mermaid people!). Great place to lay in the sun with a book and salmon sandwich... and maybe a bag of pita chips...

Note: This is the equivalant of San Carlos Beach in Monterey, with nice housing & condos nearby.
author: Eugene G.

description:
Wow, what a view!  
This beach is located in the hotey-toyey neighborhood of Sea Cliff, where celebs like Robin Williams, reside.   A couple of homes for sale in the neighborhood are well over $2 milliion and one was asking for over $4 million.  But, you can purchase a condo for a "mere" 800K! 
From the street level parking lot, you walk a few feet thru a gated area and there's an engraved granite slab from the 1980's, commemorating the history of this beach as a campsite used by Chinese fisherman during the Gold Rush days.  You get a great view of the ocean from the far west tip of San Francisco, outside and beyond the Golden Gate Bridge.  Across the street in one of the "monster homes" is a Swiss flag mounted up front.  Perched on top of high cliffs over the beach are several more multimillion dollar "monster homes" with what I can only imagine, breathtaking views.   But, there is a drawback with  the large blackbirds and seagulls surfing the winds adjacent or above the homes.  Can you imagine all the bird turd?

You descend mud slab stairs bracketed by wood onto a platform where you can watch the white tops on the waters. There are a couple of benches.  Further down, is a paved area with one BBQ pit and another set of stairs down to the tiny beach.  It can be very cold and windy but awesome to watch the ships come into the Bay and under the bridge.
author: Ry T.

description: China Beach has a great view of the Golden Gate Bridge and is a relaxing spot for everyone.  As you stroll down the steps you can imagine being somewhere else far away from the daily routine. Kind of  like a mini-vacation. Just feel the cool breeze. enjoy
author: Richard W.

description: The best hidden secret in San Francisco.  We went to take photos at sunset and saw a fantastic show of 15 or so dolphins playing right in front of us!  Perfect photo spot too.
author: Helen T.

description:
Amazing beach with very few people. It's not your conventional touristy beach as it is on the small side and the pretty hefty amount of stairs can deter some people, however once you get there the view is quite incredible.
It has your typical beach services as far as I could tell like bathrooms and showers.
Great place to watch a sunset with a special someone =). The only drawback is that they enforce the sunset closing time quite strictly which can be a minor nuisance. A policeman actually drove down to ensure that everyone left only 10 minutes after the sun was out!

Other than that, absolutely great place for some privacy and a great view.
author: Kevin G.

description:
Shh... no one's supposed to know about this.

Although it is accessible by a less treacherous fireroad, I would not recommend this beach for people with mobility restrains. For those able and willing, this is absolutely a great spot to jet down to for a quick respite from City Living.

It does, though, get very crowded on sunny days and parking is limited. Oh, and the sand can get deceptively hot even on overcast days. 

I lost my glasses there in the water once...
author: H S.

description: China Beach is my favorite beach in the city. Granted, I'm only really comparing it to Ocean Beach and Baker Beach... but it is better! It would get 5 stars, but it evidently is not dog-friendly, which means I can't take my baby there! But, it is beautiful, with stunning views of the GG bridge. I love the general lack of crowds, and especially how it is tucked away in the gorgeousness of Seacliff. There is always parking too! My husband and I took our engagement photos there, and the beach made for a stunning backdrop. It's a great place for locals, so check it out if you get a chance!
author: Bridgette A.

description: This is a horrible horrible beach.  Never ever go there.  You will have a horrible time.  It is chock-full of wild dogs and raving lunatics and bats - bats that swoop down and attack during the day time.  And the sharks  - they come snapping right up on the sand.  This beach is filthy dirty and covered in hypodermic needles and naked people.  The riptide will suck you right out to Japan.  Stay away from China Beach.  The worst in the City. .
author: Robyn C.

description: I love it here.  I especially love coming here on Sundays after eating a nice brunch with friends.  Or by myself, or really whenever I get the chance to.  The views are amazing and its one of the few places that I instantly feel immediately relaxed.  If you haven't been, then you best be getting your beach on!
author: Karen K.

description: Wedged in between Baker's Beach and Lands End, but not connected to either by trail, and hardly visible at all unless you're already right on top of it, you're unlikely to ever find China Beach by accident.  Sure, it's a great little pocket of nature with views of the GGB, but the overbearing infrastructure here (giant parking lot, chain link fence, driving ramp, huge concrete bulwarks, and that crumbling, yellow eyesore of a building) detract a lot.  If you really want a pristine spot, I recommend walking out to Mile Rock Beach.  But China Beach is still an essential addition to any local's box of secret spots.
author: Wes M.

description:
92 steps down to childhood.
if i were a whale i would want to be beached here. mainly because i would take up majority of this tiny beach..... and partially because Robin Williams owns property nearby, and maybe just MAYBE being beached nearby would grant me a chance to meet him!

but on the beach note, its tiny, beautiful, great view of the bay, never TOO crowded, parking right above the 92 steps and has a lot of history. yay.
author: Helen N.

description: I can't believe that in the six years I've been living here that I've never set foot on China Beach.  A friend and I went here today (first time for her too) and even though it was showering, overcast and cold, the beach offers a great view of the bridge and the bay.  And there were only about a half-dozen other people around, which made the visit seem a little private. I would put this on a list of places I would recommend to visitors, but I can't imagine actually coming here for the beach.  Where I'm from, the beaches have white sand and the ocean is green-blue.
author: Keith K.

description: What a beautiful, hidden gem in the city...Breathtaking views of the GGB add to the beauty of this place.  Good place to sit down and let out a big sigh.  *Sigh
author: Chai S.

description: On a sunny, not-so-windy day, China Beach is a hidden jewel within the Sea Cliff neighborhood of San Francisco.  You can't miss Robin Williams pink corner house(look for a metal rendition of a dinosaur in the front yard) facing the beach...this beach is intimate, is flanked by caves and has a spectacular view of Marin Headlands and the GG bridge.  When the tide is low, you can walk straight through to Baker Beach and discover the sea animals (starfish, anemones, jellyfish) decorating the rocks and caves...Also the nooks and crannies give you privacy when you're feeling "From Here to Eternity" with your honey.
author: Jaena G.

description: My wife and I were casually walking along the Land's End Trail for the first time when we found ourselves meandering through the gorgeous Sea Cliff neighborhood.  A moment of enchantment was followed by a period of rage.  WTF?  People get to privatize pieces of land next to the ocean with their own private view.  An ocean view should be everyone's birthright.   Damn it, I'm starting to feel like I need score some justice for Oscar Grant - and I'm not interested in nabbing shoes at the Downtown Oakland Foot Locker...I'm about to put a brick through Robin Williams' window.  Finally, a sign pointing to a public beach soothes my rage.  Hours of reflective glances out into the ocean, examining the crashes of the waves and while considering the incredible properties of light, sand, and water, refreshed my soul and allowed for me to be a kinder, less violent person upon leaving.  The beach is small but nice.  I could have lived without the old man sun bathing in his tighty whiteys - c'mon now, you're a grown man, get a bathing suit!
author: Thomas S.

description:
China Beach is one of the spots in the city that make me think San Francisco really is one of the coolest cities in the world. This beach, small and surrounded by cliffs, is a great respite from the busy city. Unlike Ocean Beach, where the crash of the waves is overshadowed by the roar of Great Highway traffic, this beach is peaceful, quieter, and rarely crowded. 
There are great views of Marin and the Golden Gate Bridge, and views of passing freighters makes you realize how gigantic those things really are. The waves are pretty gentle, and so the beach is nice for swimming if you are crazy enough to jump into the muscle-achingly cold water. (People were swimming laps out there today, but don't be fooled: the water is very, very cold.) Also check out the wierd, red old guys sunning themselves on the sun deck. 
I saw several sets of dolphins out there today; they were surfacing and diving right off shore, it was unbelievable. The rocks around also contain plenty of invertebrate life, so if you are into tide-pooling-like activities, check out the rocks. There are sea anemones, crabs, shellfish, and the occasional brightly-colored jellyfish clinging to the sides of the partially submerged rocks. 
Additional credit for the fact that China Beach is an easy, flat, pleasant bikeride from the Inner Sunset.
author: Kathleen B.

description: This is everyone's little secret, but now that I have gone back, I keep seeing more and more people. Love this beach! It is a good place to take it all in and because the sand is darker here than a lot of beaches, it's warmer and great to lay out on.  Usually some families here, but never too many people. It usually never seems crowded. Racing up the stairs is fun and is good exercise. Great view of the bridge and Tennessee Point.
author: Russell S.

description: Picturesque, peaceful place. Some of the best views of the Golden Gate Bridge in the Bay Area.It has a welcome secluded effect due to the rocks, hills, and vegetation. The only problem is the wind and cold.
author: Anonymous P.

description: If you're looking for a nice, secluded little getaway...this is your beach. I've never seen more than half a dozen people milling about, so things are pretty private. This is a great destination for a bike ride. One of my favorite past times is perching atop some giant rock, putting back a few beers with a friend and just enjoying the views.
author: Steven C.

description: Beautiful people, young and trendy crowd hang out on this part of China Beach which borders Baker Beach. Baker Beach draws in a different crowd but China Beach is definitely trendier with lots of "nice" bodies hanging out, reading, relaxing, playing frisbies and playing catch with their dogs. Safe haven for women without being oogled at.
author: Yan M.

description: One of the better beaches in San Francisco. This is definitely not Ocean Beach. This has a more peaceful, intimate setting and I notice not as much people come here because it's hidden behind all those million dollar homes in the Sea Cliff district. This is their backyard, but you are free to check it out and pretend you live in one of their mini mansions. Nice place to take a walk with your hunnybunny as you admire the postcard view of the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Zell C.

description: The smell of the sewage almost prevented me from walking down to this beach. I trekked down, only to find sewage spilling out onto the beach.... where kids were PLAYING in it. I walked back up and drove away. China Beach isn't gonna work.
author: Amanda H.

description:
No pets allowed on China Beach.  

After reading some reviews on yelp that mentioned dogs, I brought my two little 6-pound dogs to China Beach.  There was a sign saying "no pets allowed."  Three separate people were kind enough (:P) to inform me on my walk down to the beach that no pets are allowed, and I was told to leave and go to Baker Beach. Which I did.
author: Quince P.

description: Shh don't tell anyone, but there's this really great beach that hardly any tourists go to.  Just try to ignore the overly tanned old people on top of the building while walking down to the beach.  They are hard core sun whorshippers. But you didn't hear this from me ;-)
author: Amanda P.

description: Although the views are stunning, the place seemed dreary (perhaps the weather?) and the bathroom structure takes up too much of the space.  In fact the smell of the bathroom sanitizer was really strong.  There seemed to be a funeral reception here today where I saw a few older men with a plastic bag of ashes.
author: Lauren S.

description: Simply put: beautiful. I absolutely loved spending the day here with, my good friend, our dogs, and Papalote burritos. A true San Francisco treat.
author: Marie B.

description: This used to be my secret spot, but then it got semi-famous. Some of my best and worst ideas were hatched here on a weekday afternoon in the sun. It's also the site of a few really nice naps.
author: Art S.

description: This is best beach in San Francisco for those that would like to relax with a wonderful view of the Golden Gate. It's never that crowded.
author: David P.

description: Beautiful views, both of the houses you pass to get there and of the GG bridge once you're at the beach. Was very clean and they honestly had the cleanest ladies room I have ever seen at a beach.  There were only like 5 other people there. The sand is nice and dark and the view is to die for. Great beach!
author: Amy T.

description: I've been here so long and never knew there is a beach tucked away in the corner of all these residential homes.  It's a great place to bbq but personally if you ask me about the beach, it isn't all that. Maybe there were so many ppl there that it looks quite dirty.  The sand has black sparkles to it so perhaps this adds to the dirtiness of the look. It's quite a small beach but the story to this beach is quite nice.  Honoring the chinese fishermans when they arrived in SF for their dedication.   It does have a good view of GGB...off to my adventure...
author: Mee-stique K.

description: Great views~ Beautiful San Francisco Beach (that is it can be a little messy)  The view of the GG bridge is fantastic! It is right near the mouth of the bay and the Pacific Ocean~
author: jen t.

description: Great spot for photos, restrooms are clean (if very dated and industrial) people have generally been friendly.  It does get COLD, but hey it's San Francisco.  No surprise there.
author: John O.

description:
This beach is never crowded.

It's perfect for enjoying the beautiful ocean and Golden Gate Bridge views with that special someone or by yourself.

It's somewhat secluded and quiet here, overlooked by a very pretty residential area. It's a nice little spot.
author: Nicole R.

description: My family used to take me here as a little kid, we never went to the other beaches because they were too crowded. I love coming here still to this day compared to the other beaches. It's just cold, that's the only problem, but hey, all beaches around here are freezing, foggy, and not what you'd expect from a California Beach. It's never crowded.
author: Adrian L.

description: I like this beach because it's kind of hidden from the public . It's surrounded by the houses of rich people . Rich people are so lucky .. it's as if they get their own beach !! lol . You can even see the butlers and servants through the window of the house across from China Beach . The windows are big and aren't curtained or anything . It's so unreal .. I thought you just see those kind of houses in movies or TV ! It makes me kind of glad I didn't grow up in one of those houses though .. I don't know , maybe just because it seems so unreal . Anyways , you have to walk down a good amount of steps to get to the beach .. the view of the beach is okay but it's kind of small . It's nice though because there's not much people so it's really quiet . It's just kind of creepy at night because it's super dark and there's like no one there . Btw , bonfires are prohibited which I think is really because then the beauty of the beach is really preserved .
author: Eileen L.

description:
decent views, but the beach is tiny tiny tiny!! it's also kind of dirty...

i prefer baker.
author: Kerry N.

description: this is my favorite beach and dont want everyone and their mothers coming here. that simple
author: Osiris Z.

description: this beach is freakin beautiful...no more is needed to say...its a must see..its really relaxing...whether you feel like relaxing or depressed this is the place to go
author: Eddie C.

description: I've had many fond memories here as a teenager and now as an adult.  I recently brought my two kids here to bask in the beauty of this beach.  We have long days just digging in the sand, dipping in our feet as the waves hit the shores, building sand castles, and taking in the breathless views of the Pacific Ocean as it meets the SF Bay under the bay bridge.
author: Maryanne D.

description: You people, you China Beach lovers, you people are CRAZY!  This beach is dirty, gross, smelly, covered in bird shit, and totally dwarfed by the giant, cement, grafitti-covered wall, which is then dwarfed by the ugliest bathroom bunker/building I have ever seen.  Sewage water comes out of pipes onto the beach (growing some fun grassy patches!).  It is true that the beach is small, not windy, and has great views, but you can only see the views if you look straight ahead and ignore the other grossnesses, so bring your blinders.  The worst.  I wish I could give it zero stars.
author: Sally C.

description: I'm amazed that this beach doesn't attract the tourists, but am extremely thankful for that, too!  Although it's gotten busier over the past few years, this beach still remains relatively peaceful, calm, and relaxing.  I'm not too fond of having to park in the neighborhood that provides access to this beach only because I feel like the people who live here don't want too many people taking up the street parking.  But then again, look at the homes here - these people probably don't park on the street.
author: Josh C.
